The Pause That Refreshes  

Jeffrey A. Rodgers is an executive vice president.  

He works at Cornish & Carey Commercial/Newmark Knight Frank.  

He learned the simple idea of pausing to refresh.  

It began when he drove home from work each evening.  

His mind was still focused on work-related projects.  

We all know this feeling.  

We may leave the office physically.  

But we are still there mentally.  

Our minds replay today’s events.  

We worry about tasks for the next day.  

Now, as he reaches his front door, he pauses.  

He applies what he calls "the pause that refreshes."  

This technique is easy.  

He stops for just a moment.  

He closes his eyes.  

He breathes in and out once.  

He breathes deeply and slowly.  

As he exhales, he lets work issues fall away.  

This allows him to enter his home with purpose.  

He can be with his family more fully.  

This supports Lao Tzu's sentiment:  

“In work, do what you enjoy.  

In family life, be completely present.”  

Thich Nhat Hanh is a Vietnamese Zen Buddhist monk.  

He is called the “world’s calmest man.”  

He explored how to live in kairos.  

He taught it as mindfulness.  

He also called it “beginner’s mind.”  

He wrote: “Mindfulness helps you go home to the present.”  

“Every time you go there and recognize happiness, happiness comes.”  

This focus on being in the moment affects everything he does.  

He takes a full hour to drink tea with other monks daily.  

He explains: “Suppose you are drinking a cup of tea.  

When you hold your cup, breathe in.  

Bring your mind back to your body.  

You become fully present.  

When you are truly there, life is present too.  

It is represented by the cup of tea.  

In that moment, you are real.  

The cup of tea is real.  

You are not lost in the past or future.  

You are not caught in projects or worries.  

You are free from all afflictions.  

In that state of freedom, you enjoy your tea.  

That is the moment of happiness and peace.  

Pay attention throughout the day for your own kairos moments.  

Write them down in your journal.  

Think about what triggered that moment.  

Consider what brought you out of it.
